description.ja: This paper describes a project to improve reading instruction in required reading courses at a private university in Japan. Beginning with a needs analysis that involved the administration of surveys to students and teachers, best practices were identified, and then an instructional DVD was produced and distributed to teachers responsible for the reading classes. Some of the teachers themselves were included on the DVD.
description.en: This paper describes a project to improve reading instruction in required reading courses at a private university in Japan. Beginning with a needs analysis that involved the administration of surveys to students and teachers, best practices were identified, and then an instructional DVD was produced and distributed to teachers responsible for the reading classes. Some of the teachers themselves were included on the DVD.

book_owner_range.ja: Chapter 6: Sort/kind of at the peripheries: Metapragmatic play and complex interactional/ textual effects in scripted dialog
book_owner_range.en: Chapter 6: Sort/kind of at the peripheries: Metapragmatic play and complex interactional/ textual effects in scripted dialog

description.ja:
The focus of Chapter 6, “Sort/kind of at the peripheries: Metapragmatic play and complex interactional / textual effects in scripted dialog,” was on trying to answer the following questions about the discourse/pragmatic markers, sort/kind of, that are known to appear at RP and LP even though they are overwhelmingly favored medially.

* Do sort/kind of function in differently at the peripheries than at medial positions?
* Does kind of function differently than sort of at the peripheries?
* Do LP and RP occurrences of sort/kind of in actual speech differ from fictional representations of them? In other words, might fiction writers and scriptwriters misrepresent or exaggerate LP and RP sort/kind of, or might they provide insights into how they function at even deeper metalinguistic levels?
description.en:
The focus of Chapter 6, “Sort/kind of at the peripheries: Metapragmatic play and complex interactional / textual effects in scripted dialog,” was on trying to answer the following questions about the discourse/pragmatic markers, sort/kind of, that are known to appear at RP and LP even though they are overwhelmingly favored medially.

* Do sort/kind of function in differently at the peripheries than at medial positions?
* Does kind of function differently than sort of at the peripheries?
* Do LP and RP occurrences of sort/kind of in actual speech differ from fictional representations of them? In other words, might fiction writers and scriptwriters misrepresent or exaggerate LP and RP sort/kind of, or might they provide insights into how they function at even deeper metalinguistic levels?

event.ja: Globalization and Localization in Computer-Assisted Language Learning (GLoCALL) Conference 2019
event.en: Globalization and Localization in Computer-Assisted Language Learning (GLoCALL) Conference 2019

location.ja: University of Foreign Language Studies at University of Da Nang, Vietnam
location.en: University of Foreign Language Studies at University of Da Nang, Vietnam

description.ja: Virtual Exchange (VE) can be a daunting process. "How does one find a partner? What platform can I use? What if something goes wrong - who will help?" These are the fears that are very real for the beginner VE practitioner. The International Virtual Exchange Project (IVEProject) was created to assuage some of those fears and to enable any language teacher to easily incorporate VE into their language classes. The IVEProject has had almost 15000 students and 200 teachers from 14 countries in South America, Asia, the Middle East, and Europe participating in a number of virtual exchanges over the last three years. Students interact asynchronously online in English as a lingua franca on a Moodle platform. Participants will outline its benefits as well as any problems they have with it. Participants will hear first-hand stories from beginner and "veteran" users of the IVEProject and will be able to decide if they wish to join it at some time in the future.
description.en: Virtual Exchange (VE) can be a daunting process. "How does one find a partner? What platform can I use? What if something goes wrong - who will help?" These are the fears that are very real for the beginner VE practitioner. The International Virtual Exchange Project (IVEProject) was created to assuage some of those fears and to enable any language teacher to easily incorporate VE into their language classes. The IVEProject has had almost 15000 students and 200 teachers from 14 countries in South America, Asia, the Middle East, and Europe participating in a number of virtual exchanges over the last three years. Students interact asynchronously online in English as a lingua franca on a Moodle platform. Participants will outline its benefits as well as any problems they have with it. Participants will hear first-hand stories from beginner and "veteran" users of the IVEProject and will be able to decide if they wish to join it at some time in the future.

description.ja: Studies looking at whether students in the US (Marin and Halpern, 2011) benefit from explicit instruction in critical thinking have concluded that they do. However, at the tertiary level it is sometimes optimistically assumed that students have mastered the basics of critical thinking earlier in their education. The speaker will demonstrate tasks designed to help university students consider multiple perspectives in order to avoid the hazards of deceptive, misleading, or biased information.

The speaker will demonstrate tasks designed to help university students consider multiple perspectives in order to avoid the hazards of deceptive, misleading, or biased information.

presentation_title.ja: Addressing the Needs of Challenging Students
presentation_title.en: Addressing the Needs of Challenging Students

location.ja: Konan University, Cube Campus, Nishinomiya, Hyogo (JAPAN)
location.en: Konan University, Cube Campus, Nishinomiya, Hyogo (JAPAN)

description.ja: In 1966 the number of 18-year-olds in Japan peaked at 2.49 million. That number shrank to 1.18 million in 2014, and the National Institute of Population and Social Security predicts that this cohort will fall below the one million mark by 2031. One consequence of this is that faculty at universities are seeing populations of students less academically prepared than they were in the past and with a wider variety of developmental, emotional, motivational, and psychological issues. Japanese universities are catching up to their western counterparts by providing an increasing array of accommodations and services for these students, but teachers are often still left to fend for themselves in finding the most effective ways to teach, evaluate, motivate, and support them. The speaker will discuss some of the institutional and teacher-generated solutions for addressing these challenges.
description.en: In 1966 the number of 18-year-olds in Japan peaked at 2.49 million. That number shrank to 1.18 million in 2014, and the National Institute of Population and Social Security predicts that this cohort will fall below the one million mark by 2031. One consequence of this is that faculty at universities are seeing populations of students less academically prepared than they were in the past and with a wider variety of developmental, emotional, motivational, and psychological issues. Japanese universities are catching up to their western counterparts by providing an increasing array of accommodations and services for these students, but teachers are often still left to fend for themselves in finding the most effective ways to teach, evaluate, motivate, and support them. The speaker will discuss some of the institutional and teacher-generated solutions for addressing these challenges.

presentation_title.ja: Helping Learners Identify Media Bias and “Fake News”
presentation_title.en: Helping Learners Identify Media Bias and “Fake News”

location.ja: Otsuma Women’s University (Tokyo)
location.en: Otsuma Women’s University (Tokyo)

description.ja: The speaker demonstrates tasks designed to help learners consider multiple perspectives on issues in order to avoid hazards of confirmation bias. These tasks include the use of specially designed websites meant to challenge students to uncover misleading information and a project investigating controversial issues while analyzing questionable sources.
description.en: The speaker demonstrates tasks designed to help learners consider multiple perspectives on issues in order to avoid hazards of confirmation bias. description.ja: Teaching is a major part of the life of teachers, but it does not tell the whole story of who they are and what they do. This forum will showcase some of the extracurricular activities of a select group of teachers and explore how those activities inform their teaching, draw from it, or provide a much-needed respite from the rigors of the chalkface. The extracurricular activities will span from drama to music and sport.
description.en: Teaching is a major part of the life of teachers, but it does not tell the whole story of who they are and what they do. This forum will showcase some of the extracurricular activities of a select group of teachers and explore how those activities inform their teaching, draw from it, or provide a much-needed respite from the rigors of the chalkface. The extracurricular activities will span from drama to music and sport.

description.ja: Service-learning combines learning objectives with community service. The speaker demonstrated how students activate their language skills while supporting activities of NPOs, incorporating their experiences into assignments and presentations. Case studies were presented of students who have volunteered for Second Harvest Japan, Doctors of the World, and other non-profits.

presentation_title.ja: A Quarter Century of the Integrated English Program: Its birth, development, current state, and future
presentation_title.en: A Quarter Century of the Integrated English Program: Its birth, development, current state, and future

promoter.ja: Japan Association of College English Teachers
promoter.en: Japan Association of College English Teachers

location.ja: Aoyama Gakuin University
location.en: Aoyama Gakuin University

description.ja: The Integrated English (IE) Program in Aoyama Gakuin University’s English Department is now in its 24th year. It is an intensive English program for freshmen and sophomores that prepares students to thrive in English-medium courses they will take in their fields of concentration in their junior and senior years. Students are streamed into one of three levels on the basis of their scores in the TOEFL ITP at the outset of their studies. The heart of the IE Program is a suite of three courses: a 4-skills Core course, an IE Writing course, and IE Active Listening. These courses are followed by an academic listening course, known as Academic Skills, and a more advanced expository writing course, Academic Writing, which helps students develop longer essays, practice critical thinking skills, and introduces them to the conventions of academic writing in greater depth.
description.en: The Integrated English (IE) Program in Aoyama Gakuin University’s English Department is now in its 24th year. It is an intensive English program for freshmen and sophomores that prepares students to thrive in English-medium courses they will take in their fields of concentration in their junior and senior years. Students are streamed into one of three levels on the basis of their scores in the TOEFL ITP at the outset of their studies. The heart of the IE Program is a suite of three courses: a 4-skills Core course, an IE Writing course, and IE Active Listening. These courses are followed by an academic listening course, known as Academic Skills, and a more advanced expository writing course, Academic Writing, which helps students develop longer essays, practice critical thinking skills, and introduces them to the conventions of academic writing in greater depth.

presentation_title.ja: From Guest Speakers to Service Learning Opportunities

location.ja: Meio University, Nago City, Okinawa Prefecture

description.ja: The presenters reported on activities that have helped adult learners develop their English competence, inferencing skills, and the ability to function effectively in bilingual working environments. Tadashi Ishida demonstrated how his mature students improved their English abilities by interacting in situations where they could use English for authentic purposes. Kathleen Yamane introduced tasks designed to help older learners develop inferencing skills to enhance the decoding process as well as their self-expression in English. Finally, Joseph Dias showed how university students were prepared for service learning placements and how it tied in with educational and career goals.

presentation_title.ja: Reducing Plagiarism In University Classes

location.ja: Meio University, Nago City, Okinawa Prefecture
location.en: Meio University, Nago City, Okinawa Prefecture

description.ja: This presentation focuses on various steps that are being implemented to reduce plagiarism in an intensive English program for first and second-year university students, based, in part, on the results of teacher and student surveys. This ongoing process has involved creating a plagiarism policy statement, providing knowledge and skill building tasks at all levels of the curriculum, creating a database of students’ work, providing teacher orientation, and creating a simple online teacher reporting form, in an effort to develop guidelines and practices that serve to educate and motivate students to avoid plagiarism, rather than simply punishing individual infractions.
description.en: This presentation focuses on various steps that are being implemented to reduce plagiarism in an intensive English program for first and second-year university students, based, in part, on the results of teacher and student surveys. This ongoing process has involved creating a plagiarism policy statement, providing knowledge and skill building tasks at all levels of the curriculum, creating a database of students’ work, providing teacher orientation, and creating a simple online teacher reporting form, in an effort to develop guidelines and practices that serve to educate and motivate students to avoid plagiarism, rather than simply punishing individual infractions.

location.en: Shizuoka Convention & Arts Center "GRANSHIP,” Shizuoka City, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan

description.ja: The speakers in this forum showed how teachers can model lifelong writing by creating teaching materials customized for their students, and by stretching their creative muscles by penning fiction for student consumption. How students can connect with audiences through their own writing will also be explored in the example of a theme-based writing exchange meant to help Japanese students identify cultural bias toward teenagers living in poverty in Cambodia.
description.en: The speakers in this forum showed how teachers can model lifelong writing by creating teaching materials customized for their students, and by stretching their creative muscles by penning fiction for student consumption. How students can connect with audiences through their own writing will also be explored in the example of a theme-based writing exchange meant to help Japanese students identify cultural bias toward teenagers living in poverty in Cambodia.

work_title.ja: A Shorter Course in Healthy Living

location.ja: Nan'un-Do Publishing Co.

work_title.ja: Misunderstandings and their repair among married couples: A pilot exploration
work_title.en: Misunderstandings and their repair among married couples: A pilot exploration

location.ja: Columbia Teachers College, MA Thesis
location.en: コロンビア大学ティーチャーズ・カレッジ MA Thesis

description.en: This is a descriptive study, employing a conversation analysis framework, of instances of misunderstanding－and their repair－in married couples. Nine married couples (some of them the same nationality and others in international marriages) were asked to record dinnertime conversations over the course of a week and then submit them to the researchers. Misunderstandings were seen broadly as A) disagreements (or, in their strong form, arguments), or B) "mistaken" interpretations of an interlocutor's utterances, as determined by subsequent or prior discourse. Self-initiated or other-initiated repair was described and analyzed along with direct or indirect styles of repair.
